questions.text: The procedure of choice for elective removal of CBD stones for most patients is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Best procedure for the elective removal of CBD stone is ERCP with papillotomy with stent placement. It is minimally invasive approach, can be done in sedation and is a day care procedure with good results and good post operative recovery. So this is the treatment of choice for elective removal of CBD stones. Open choledocholithotomy is performed when CBD stones are detected intra operatively and the operating surgeon is not skilled to perform a laparoscopic CBD exploration. Laparoscopic choledocholithotomy is performed when CBD stones are detected intraoperatively and surgeon is skilled in laparoscopic CBD exploration.

questions.text: The Reynold's pentad of fever, jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, septic shock and mental status change is typical of: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cholangiitis typically presents with charcot’s triad comprising of abdominal pain + Jaundice + Fever. Cholangiitis can be self limiting or it can progress to toxic symptoms and severe illness including jaundice, fever, abdominal pain, mental status changes, and hypotension . These constellation of symptoms are referred to as Reynold’s pentad. Hepatitis usually presents as right upper quadrant pain with fever and raised liver enzymes, jaundice and septic shock is not a typical feature of hepatitis. Pancreatitis will present as a sharp pain in the epigastric region radiating to the back .

choices.text: Associated with GB stones in 10% cases
Laboratory values may be normal in one third cases of choledocholithiasis
Residual stones are discovered after 2 years of cholecystectomy

questions.text: All are true about CBD stones except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Stones which are discovered within 2 years of cholecystectomy are referred to as residual stones Stones which are discovered after 2 years of cholecystectomy are referred to as recurrent stones Option A is correct as 10 % of patients who have gall bladder stones also have a CBD stone. Option B is correct as primary CBD stones are the ones which are formed in the CBD because of an underlying infection and so they tend to be brown in colour. Secondary CBD stones are the ones which have formed in gall bladder and have migrated in the CBD from above, they tend to be cholesterol stones. Option C is correct as lab values can be normal in one third of the cases of choledocholithiasis and so the IOC is ERCP.

questions.text: Which of the following calculi are rare in gallbladder, but common in common bile duct?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) brown stones are common in bile duct and rare in gall bladder. They are caused because of some underlying infection and stasis of bile and are formed primarily in the CBD. Option A is the cholesterol stone and it is the most common type of stone in gall bladder and formed in gall bladder itself. Option C that is pure black stones are very rare and can occur in haemolytic disorders.

questions.text: Charcot's triad: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cholangitis is characterized by Charcot’s triad that is Abdominal pain, jaundice and fever. After this cholangitis can be either self limited or it can progress to Reynold’s pentad which comprises of jaundice, fever, abdominal pain, mental status changes, and hypotension .

questions.text: Sphincterotomy of sphincter of Oddi is performed at: (AIIMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) TRANSDUODENAL SPHINCTEROPLASTY • In this cut is made superiorly (at the 11 o’clock position) for 4 to 5 mm. •The sphincter is incised at the 11 O’clock position to avoid injury to the pancreatic duct.

questions.text: Most common cause of cholangiitis: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Causes of Cholangitis are • Choledocholithiasis (MC) • Benign strictures • Biliary-enteric anastomotic strictures •Cholangiocarcinoma and periampullary cancer Option A and D that is viral infections and amoebic abscess on their own as a cause of cholangitis is uncommon.

questions.text: What is more appropriate for diagnosis of CBD stones? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) USG is the first line test which can document GB stones and estimate the CBD diameter. A dilated bile duct (>8 mm in diameter) in a patient with gallstones, jaundice and biliary pain is highly suggestive of choledocholithiasis. ERCP is diagnostic and therapeutic test of choice for patients with suspected CBD stones. Oral cholangiography and IV Cholangiography are not used for the diagnosis of CBD Stones.

questions.text: In cholangiitis, the organism mostly responsible is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cholangitis occurs because of ascending bacterial infection of the biliary ductal system with obstruction. MC cause of acute cholangiitis is choledocholithiasis. Most common organisms present in the bile in patients with cholangitis is E. coli. Other organisms which can be present are klebsiella pneumoniae, Streptococcus faecalis, and Bacteroides fragilis.

questions.text: Ramu presents with recurrent attacks of cholelithiasis, USG examination shows a dilated CBD of 1 cm, The next line of management is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) This question talks about a patient who has recurrent attacks of cholelithiasis, and on USG we have a CBD which is 1 cm dilated. USG is the screening test and the above findings are suggestive of CBD stone leading to biliary obstruction. In order to confirm the diagnosis we need to carry out ERCP as ERCP is diagnostic as well as therapeutic for CBD stone. Option B that is percutaneous cholangiography is done if ERCP fails. Option C is the next step once the diagnosis of CBD stone has been made. Intravenous cholangiogram does not helps in making the diagnosis of CBD stone with accuracy.

choices.text: Slight flow of dye from the sides

questions.text: In cholangiography CBD stone appears as: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) On MR cholangiography, typical meniscus sign is seen when CBD stone is wedged at the level of the papilla. Cut off sign is not a feature of CBD stones.

choices.text: Carcinoma of the head of the pancreas

questions.text: An ultrasound examination shows dilated intrahepatic biliary channels with a small gallbladder. The most likely possibility is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option C is the answer in this question as this question talks about the scenario where an obstruction to the biliary drainage has occurred due to CBD stone and the most common source is slippage of stone from gall bladder into the biliary tree. If there occurs an obstructive jaundice the biliary radicals along with gall bladder is distended but if there has been a gall bladder stone for a significant amount of time then these stones tend to lead to fibrosis of the gall bladder and if this happens then the gall bladder can not be distended because it has undergone fibrosis. If there occurs an obstruction of biliary tree because of carcinoma head of pancreas then gall bladder along with the biliary tree would be distended. Option A that is gall bladder stone and Option B that is pancreatic calculi will not lead to biliary obstruction on its own.

choices.text: Cancer of the ampulla of vater

questions.text: The most common cause of suppurative cholangiitis is: (AIIMS May 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CBD stones are very common and it leads to biliary stasis and then there occurs infection in the stagnated bile over a period of time leading to suppurative cholangiitis. Thus CBD stones are the most common cause of suppurative cholangiitis. Carcinoma of ampulla of vater presents as obstructive jaundice in most of the cases and it leading to cholangitis is rare. Choledochal cyst presents as mass, fever and jaundice and it can lead to cholangitis but it is a rare condition.

questions.text: The procedure of choice for elective removal of CBD stones for most patients is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Procedure of choice for elective removal of CBD stones is endoscopic choledocholithotomy via ERCP. It is a minimally invasive procedure and is very effective in removal of the CBD stones and it serves as a diagnostic as well as therapeutic intervention so it is the procedure of choice. Option A Open choledocholithotomy is done when ERCP is not available or has failed and surgeon does not have experience in laparoscopic CBD exploration. Option C laparoscopic choledocholithotomy is done when ERCP is not available or has failed and surgeon has good experience in laparoscopic CBD exploration. Option D that is percutaneous choledocholithotomy is preferred when intrahepatic stones are present or there is obstruction in the proximal biliary tree.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Reynolds' Pentad in toxic cholangiitis? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Cholangiitis is characterized by Charcot’s triad that is Abdominal pain, jaundice and fever. After this cholangitis can be either self limited or it can progress to Reynold’s pentad which comprises of jaundice, fever, abdominal pain, mental status changes, and hypotension .

questions.text: All of the following are seen with bile duct stone except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option B is wrong as if the patient has obstructive jaundice because of CBD stone then there is high likelihood that the gall bladder would have been fibrosed already due to chronic insult and injury by the stones in gall bladder to the mucosa of the gall bladder wall. So if this has occurred we wont get distended and palpable gall bladder. Option A is right as if we have a CBD stone there is high likelihood that patient will have an obstructive jaundice. Option C and D are the features of obstructive jaundice and will be present in CBD stone as it leads to obstructive jaundice. Courvoisier law : In a patient with obstructive jaundice , Gall bladder is seldom palpable due to stone disease. Exceptions to Courvoisier law : A) Primary CBD stone B) Double impacted stone C) Chinese liver fluke infection

questions.text: Management of stone in CBD includes following except: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option A is not the answer as if we have diagnosed a patient with CBD stone we don’t just sit and expect the stone to pass through CBD into duodenum on its own it is just not possible. Option D is endosphincteric removal of stone this can be done via ERCP and is the IOC for diagnosis as well as treatment of CBD stones. Option B and C can also be performed as a treatment option of CBD stone depending on the various factors and expertise of the surgeon. But just observation as a treatment option is never done.

choices.text: Lap CBD exploration and stone removal
Lap CBD extraction through the cystic duct
Convert to open cholecystectomy and CBD stone removal

questions.text: A surgeon with less experience of laparoscopic cholecystectomy while doing laparoscopic surgery found some stone in CBD. What should he ideally do? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In this question the answer is option D as surgeon is less experienced with laparoscopic cholecystectomy and he sees stones in CBD the best thing he can do is convert the operation to an open procedure and do a cholecystectomy with CBD stone removal. We need to perform choledochoduodenostomy when we have some stricture pathology in the the distal part of CBD. As surgeon is less experienced with laparoscopic cholecystectomy option B and C are not possible to be done by this surgeon properly. If the surgery would have been experienced, then Laparoscopic cholecystectomy+ Laparoscopic evaluation of CBD. If Laparoscopic exploration of CBD is not possible than open exploration is to be done

questions.text: Choledochotomy is indicated in all of the following except in patients with: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Absolute indications of choledochotomy are : Palpable CBD stones Jaundice with cholangitis Demonstration of stone on intra-operative cholangiography CBD diameter >12 mm Coming to option C, Alkaline phosphatase is raised in cases of obstructive jaundice and as if it is raised it is an indicator that there is some distal obstruction. Option D is false as gamma glutamyl transferase is not elevated in patients with obstructive jaundice so if that is raised it is not an indication for choledochotomy.

questions.text: Best suture for common bile duct is: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Synthetic absorbable suture such as Vicryl and PDS is preferred for CBD. Vicryl sutures are used in general soft tissue approximation and are preferred suture material for CBD. Non absorbable sutures ordinarily remain where they are buried within the tissues. This can cause late complications such as the development of Gallstones around non-absorbable sutures in the common bile duct or bladder stones in the urinary bladder. Option B and D are wrong because if we use non absorbable material then there occurs increased chance of stone formation as the non-absorbable suture acts as a nucleating agent. Option C is wrong as if we use natural absorbable suture it will cause severe tissue reaction and might lead to cholangiitis and stricture.

questions.text: After exploration of common bile duct, the T-tube is removed on which of the following days:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) If we perform an open choledochotomy there is a trend to keep a T-tube in the bile duct. The purpose of the T tube is to provide access to the biliary system for postoperative radiologic stone extraction and allow spasm or edema of sphincter to settle. The protocol which we follow is that we perform a post operative cholangiogram on day 7-10th , if this cholangiogram findings are normal we can procede and remove the T-tube on post operative day 12th. But If T-tube cholangiogram shows retained stones we have to keep the T-tube for 6 weeks as a stent so that the track matures and then stones can be removed percutaneously from this matured track by putting a choledochoscope and this is referred to as Burrhene’s technique.

questions.text: After cholecystectomy a 2.5 cm calculus was found in CBD, treatment for this should be:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Option B and C are the the procedures used for CBD stones by the use of ERCP but there are few conditions in which we can not perform ERCP like stones>1.5 cm, multiple gall stones, impacted stones and in these conditions open choledochotomy is preferred and we have to perform a supraduodenal choledochotomy. As in this question we have a calculus of 2.5 cm in CBD we can not perform ERCP in this scenario and have to go for supraduodenal choledochotomy.

questions.text: Most common complication of common bile duct exploration: (AIIMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) When you find stones in the bile duct during the process of cholecystectomy we have to do bile duct exploration. It is not uncommon for stones to still be present in the bile duct due to improper evacuation of the stones, this condition is called as retained stones in the bile duct. This is the most common complication of bile duct exploration . Pancreatitis is a complication of ERCP and is not common after CBD exploration. If patient is subjected to ERCP as a treatment option for CBD stone he might develop pancreatitis . Stricture in the CBD can occur following bile duct exploration but it is not the most common complication. T-tube displacement is another complication which can occur after bile duct exploration.

choices.text: Incidence is equal in laparoscopic and open cholecystectomy
After experience of 20 cases, bile duct injury rate decreases
Errors leading to laparoscopic bile duct injuries stem from misperception, not errors of skill, knowledge or judgment
Primary cause of error in most of the cases is visual perceptual illusion

questions.text: All are true about bile duct injury except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Incidence of bile duct injury is more in laparoscopic cholecystectomy as compared to open cholecystectomy. Incidence of bile duct injury during open cholecystectomy is 0.1–0.2%. Incidence of bile duct injury during laparoscopic cholecystectomy is 0.3–0.85% As surgeon experience increases beyond 20 cases, the bile duct injury rate decreases. Errors leading to laparoscopic bile duct injuries stem from ‘misperception’, not errors of skill, knowledge or judgment. The primary cause of error in 97% cases was a ‘visual perceptual illusion’, whereas only 3% injuries were due to faults of technical skills.

questions.text: According to Strasberg classification, lateral CBD injuries are classified as: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Let us first look at the Strasberg classification of biliary injury Type A Bile leaks from minor ducts still in continuity with the CBD. Includes leakage from cystic duct stump and from the subvesical duct of Luschka Most common cause of biliary leaks seen after laparoscopic cholecystectomy Type B Occlusion of a part of the biliary tree ,almost always an aberrant right sectoral duct As there is no bile leak ERCP finding is normal Type C Transection without ligation of an aberrant right sectoral duct Type D A lateral injury to an extrahepatic duct Type E1: Low common hepatic stricture, hepatic duct stump > 2cm Type E2: Mid common hepatic duct stump <2cm Type E3: Hilar stricture , no hepatic duct stump, confluence intact Type E4: Destruction of the hilar confluence , right and left hepatic ducts are separated Type E5: Involvement of aberrant right sectoral hepatic duct alone with or without a concomitant hepatic duct stricture

questions.text: According to the Bismuth/Strasberg classification, cystic blowout is classified as: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Note that cystic blowout is classified as Type A of bismuth/Strasberg classification. Type B Occlusion of a part of the biliary tree almost always an aberrant right sectoral duct As there is no bile leak ERCP finding is normal Type C Transection without ligation of an aberrant right sectoral duct Type D A lateral injury to an extrahepatic duct

choices.text: Order an urgent endoscopic retrograde cholangiography and biliary stenting
Order an urgent hepatic imino diacetic acid scintigraphy (HIDA)

questions.text: A 40-years old patient has undergone an open cholecystectomy. The procedure was reported as uneventful by the operating surgeon. She has 100 ml of bile output from the drain kept in the gallbladder bed on the first post operative day. On examination she is afebrile and anicteric. The abdomen is soft and bowel sounds are normally heard. As an attending physician, what should be your best possible advice: (AIIMS May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Patients who develop jaundice in the postoperative period require urgent investigation. This is especially true if the jaundice is associated with infection, a condition called cholangiitis. Since the patient is afebrile and anicteric, Clinical observation is the best possible advice

choices.text: Laparotomy and surgical exploration of bile duct and T-tube insertion
Laparoscopic cystic duct ligation and percutaneous drainage

questions.text: On 5th postoperative day after laparoscopic cholecystectomy, a 50 years old lady presented with right upper quadrant pain with fever and 12 cm subhepatic collection on CT and ERCP shows cystic duct leak. The best management is: (PGI May 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Patients who develop jaundice in the postoperative period require urgent investigation. This is especially true if the jaundice is associated with infection, a condition called cholangiitis. The first step in management following resuscitation and administration of appropriate antibiotics is to undertake an urgent ultrasound scan. This will demonstrate whether there is intra- or extrahepatic ductal dilatation. The anatomy needs to be defined by either an ERCP or a MRCP. The former will also allow therapeutic manoeuvres. As ERCP Shows Cystic duct leak ,ligate the cystic duct with With Laproscopy and as there is subhepatic collection of fluid drain the fluid with percutaneous drainage .

choices.text: The incidences following open cholecystectomy is in the range of 0.2 to 0.3%
The incidence rate following laparoscopic cholecystectomy is three times higher than the rates following open Cholecystectomy
Untreated cases may develop secondary biliary cirrhosis
Routine use of 'open' technique of laparoscopic port insertion has resulted in a decline in the incidence of post laparoscopic cholecystectomy bile duct injuries

questions.text: Regarding bile duct injuries following cholecystectomy which of the following statement is false? (AIIMS Nov 2014)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Biliary injury in laparoscopic cholecystectomies are not related to port insertion technique, they are associated with visual perception error leading to confusion in interpreting the anatomy of the biliary system intraoperatively. It is not because of any lack of knowledge or skills of the surgeon . Option A is correct as incidence of biliary injury following open cholecystectomy is in the range of 0.2-0.3 % Incidence of biliary injury is more following laparoscopic cholecystectomy,It is three times that with open cholecystectomy. If there is inadvertent ligation of a duct draining a particular portion of the liver it can lead to biliary cirrhosis.

questions.text: Common bile duct injuries are most commonly seen in: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Most common cause of biliary injury is iatrogenic and most common operation associated with biliary injury is laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Radical gastrectomy is rarely associated with biliary injury. Most common organ injured in penetrating injury of abdomen is liver but this leads to bleeding from liver and hemoperitoneum in most of the cases rather than biliary injury. ERCP with sphincterotomy does not lead to common bile duct injury infact this intervention helps in the treatment of the minor bile duct injuries.

choices.text: Involvement of secondary biliary radicals bilaterally
Involvement of right branch of portal vein

questions.text: Non-resectability criteria in hilar cholangiocarcinoma are all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) involvement of right or left branch of portal vein is not a criteria of non respectability, if there is encasement or blockage of main portal vein proximal to its bifurcation it becomes a criteria for unresectability. Options A is correct as involvement of secondary biliary radicals bilaterally is a criteria for non resectability of the tumour. Option B is correct as metastasis to celiac nodes is a criteria for non resectability of the tumour. Option D is also correct as contralateral involvement of bile duct is a criteria for non resectability of cholangiocarcinoma.

choices.text: Tumour involving the main biliary confluence but not extending into individual ducts

questions.text: Type II cholangiocarcinoma involve: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Bismuth-Corlette Classification of Hilar Cholangiocarcinoma I: Tumor confined to hepatic duct, not involving the main biliary confluence II: Tumor involving the main biliary confluence but not extending to the right or left ducts IIIa: Tumor extending upto the right secondary biliary confluence IIIb: Tumor extending upto the left secondary biliary confluence IV: Tumor extending bilaterally to the secondary biliary confluence

choices.text: Scirrhous type has better prognosis than papillary
Major prognostic factors are margin status and tumor stage
Bile duct resection alone is associated with high chances of recurrence
Curative resection includes hepatic resection + bile duct resection + lymphadenectomy

questions.text: All are true about prognosis of cholangiocarcinoma except: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cholangiocarcinoma is basically of 3 types: Sclerosing or Scirrhous, nodular and papillary. Sclerosing or scirrhous type is the one which is most common type, it has intense desmoplastic reaction and it is very difficult to treat so has a poor prognosis. Papillary carcinoma on the other hand is a rare variety and tends to grow into the lumen and has a favourable prognosis. Option B is correct as margin status and tumour stage determines a major prognostic factor in cholangiocarcinoma. Bile duct resection alone is associated with high chance of recurrence and so for stablishing complete cure we need to go for hepatic resection + bile duct resection + lymphadenectomy.

questions.text: Most common site of cholangiocarcinoma: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cholangiocarcinoma can be intrahepatic, hilar or distal. Out of these three Hilar variety is the most common one(65%) , followed by distal cholangiocarcinoma (25%) and proximal variety comprises only 10 % of the total. Hilar cholangiocarcinoma is also known as Klatskin tumor.

choices.text: Hepatic duct involvement upto secondary radicals bilaterally
Encasement or occlusion of main portal vein proximal to its bifurcation
Atrophy of one lobe with encasement of contralateral portal vein branch
Atrophy of one lobe with ipsilateral involvement of secondary biliary radicals

questions.text: All are criteria of non-resectability in patients with hilar cholangiocarcinoma except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Please note that atrophy of one lobe with ipsilateral involvement of secondary biliary radicals is not a criteria of non resectability. Following are the criteria’s for non resectability: • Hepatic duct involvement up to secondary radicals bilaterally • Encasement or occlusion of the main portal vein proximal to its bifurcation • Atrophy of one lobe with encasement of contralateral portal vein branch • Atrophy of one lobe with contralateral involvement of secondary biliary radicals • Histologically proven metastasis to N2 lymph nodes • Liver, lung or peritoneal metastasis

questions.text: Not true of hemobilia: (AIIMS Nov 2015)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hemobilia is characterized by Quincke’s triad which comprises of GI haemorrhage, biliary colic and jaundice. Fever Is not a feature of hemobilia.

questions.text: Cause of hemobilia are all except: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Option A is correct as trauma is the most common cause of hemobilia. Most common cause in trauma is iatrogenic trauma caused by PTC that is percutaneous transhepatic cholangiography. And overall blunt trauma is more common cause of hemobilia than penetrating trauma. Option B is malignancy like cholangiocarcinoma is also one of the causes of hemobilia. Option C is correct as vascular causes like aneurysm, angiodysplasia and hemangioma can also lead to hemobilia. Option D is the answer to this question as hepatitis is not a cause of hemobilia

choices.text: MC cause- rupture of portal vein into biliary system

questions.text: True regarding hemobilia: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) hemobilia is characterized by Quinke’s triad which comprises of GI haemorrhage, biliary colic and jaundice. Option B is wrong as the most common cause of hemobilia is iatrogenic. IOC in Haemobilia is CT angiography.

questions.text: A patient has a surgical cause of obstructive jaundice. USG can tell all of the following except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Option A is biliary tree obstruction and USG gives us a good idea about presence of biliary tree obstruction as we can see dilated biliary radicals in it. Option C is gall bladder stones and they can be easily picked up by USG and infact USG is the investigation of choise for GB Stones. Option D is ascites, and USG is a good investigation to look for ascites. Option B is the answer as USG can not pick up peritoneal deposits, CT scan is a better investigation for this as compared to USG but the best investigation is diagnostic laparoscopy.

questions.text: Most common surgical cause of obstructive jaundice: (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) the most common cause of surgically correctable obstructive jaundice is CBD stones. Option A, B and C can also lead to obstructive jaundice but the most common among the above is CBD stone.

questions.text: Best test to differentiate between medical and surgical jaundice is? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) USG is the best test to distinguish between surgical and medical jaundice, in USG one can see the dilated biliary radicals which are suggestive of obstruction in the biliary tract. About option A :- Alkaline phosphatase is also one of the enzymes which can be used to screen the patients of obstructive jaundice but USG is better investigation than this.

questions.text: Which is not elevated in a child presenting with jaundice, icterus, pruritus and clay colored stools? (LQ)
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Glutamate dehydrogenase is not elevated in child presenting with obstructive jaundice. Enzymes elevated in obstructive jaundice are : Alkaline phosphatase 5-nucleotidase Gamma glutamyl transpeptidase.

questions.text: Identify the investigation performed in the following image .
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) A t-tube cholangiogram is a special x-ray procedure that is done with contrast media (x-ray dye) to visualize the bile ducts after the removal of the gallbladder. The bile ducts drain bile from the liver into the duodenum (first part of the small bowel). This procedure will visualize any stones remaining in the bile ducts.

choices.text: Results in fibrosis of only extrahepatic biliary channel

questions.text: False about primary sclerosing cholangitis is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Primary Sclerosing cholangitis has a genetic predisposition owing its association with ulcerative colitis. The diagnosis is principally based on the findings at cholangiography, in which irregular, narrowed bile ducts are demonstrated in both the intrahepatic and the extrahepatic biliary tree. This condition often presents in young adults with mild non-specific symptoms. There is no specific treatment that can reverse the ductal changes, and the patients usually slowly progress to progressive cholestasis and death from liver failure. Serum CA 19-9 level may be increased but the sensitivity of CA 19-9 in detecting CCA in PSC is only 60%. Patients with good liver function, no dominant strictures and negative biliary cytology may simply be monitored for disease progression. The only useful treatment modality is liver transplantation, which is associated with excellent results if carried out before bile duct cancer has developed.
